content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												During the Pre-release stage of this game, skirmishes were promised against AI or Human players; Steam even had the feature on the store page as well.  After watching the DEV-team videos and listening to what they were "promising" I decided to pre-order it (pre-ordered it the day before it came out).Fast Forward a day and stronghold 3 was released. The features that I had purchased this game for were missing from the in-game menu and when I got out to check the store page they had removed at least half of the bullet points for what this game was promising. Fraud? The game itself is riddled with issues; path-finding, graphical mishaps, and the beloved soldiers mixed with wall syndrome.  The skirmish is no longer a skirmish of any sort but a rather boring and pointless sandbox free-build mode where you build a glitched-out castle on one of 7 tiny maps.The campaign itself is TERRIBLE. The cutscenes are storyboards, which they try to play off as art (something only BL2 was able to pull off without it seeming like the game was rushed and released without polish).Dont buy this game. Dont buy any games from the criminals at Firefly, i wouldnt purchase this game for $0.50 and it was the last game I have or will ever pre-order. It's worth noting that after reading reviews of their newest "game" it appears that much of the same happened yet again. They simply cash in on a halfway decent game that was made 20 years ago without putting forth much effort to change or enhance anything. Terrible company, terrible games, and terrible ethics.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												I'm sure there are already enough negative comments to ward off even the stupidest buyer but I'm going to add mine anyway because leaving a negative comment is the only enjoyment I get from this game. The initial release of Stronghold 3 may be the most shameful act in gaming history. If this were Japan, the staff of Firefly would be honor bound to commit Hari-Kari. Like so many others I have been with the Stronghold Series from the start; absolutely one of my favorites until...Stronghold 3. It was more than a slap in the face to fans of the series. It was an insult to the entire gaming community. It was months late from its expected arrival. Each delay accompanied by an assurance they were refining the game. What they were doing was hurriedly hacking together a cheap revised version of SH2. Even though the "frankenstein" they had created still lacked life, they released it upon the world, in time for the Christmas market. Thanks to trusting fans and unwary buyers the game went gold immediately. The scheme had worked perfectly. They dangled it front of us with a lot of hype [lies], made a fortune in initial sales, delivered a bonified POC, figuring to patch the monster together in the following months. And then failed to deliver on that as well. Here's an example of the refinements they were making. I call it, Mission: ImpossibleOne of the first missions is to defend the town from wolf attacks. I built 2 wooden towers with ladder access, put archers in them to intercept the wolves and reduce their numbers as they approached the town. The wolves came, climbed the ladders into the towers and killed my archers. Any playtesting at all could not miss this.If releasing this abomination upon a trusting fan base wasn't despicable enough; consider how they treated the foreign markets. The Chinese were sold a retail copy that could not be converted to a Steam account. That meant they had no access to any patches except if a kind soul posted a cracked version somewhere. Let me say it again. They sold the Chinese unplayable versions of the game with no support. Anything for a buck.I don't care what excuse they give for their actions. They cheated me. They cheated the world. And there's been no retribution for the crime. Firefly is dead to me. I don't look at anything that has their logo on it. There's plenty of new, respectable talent and castle building games are coming on all the time. Firefly should stick to games about organized crime anyway. That's where their true talent lies.

number of helpful: 303 of 316 people (96%) found this review helpful14 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												I've had a few attempts playing this game, let me summarise:At launch:  a buggy mess, a festival of bugs and crashes and AI/UI issues.  You could not place certain (crucial) structures like steps .. which would allow you to mount archers on the walls.  Archers did not return fire as mace-men approached your walls.  It was a ridiculous and frustrating mess.  Only positive I can say is I liked some of the gritty art style.A few months later:  it seemed like the developer was as disappointed as most consumers .. there was apparently some advices saying they blamed the publisher who pushed for an early release, and that they would endeavour to give consumers the game that they deserve through patching and constant and consistent after-sale improvements.  (Apparently the game we deserve is 'poo poo' because even with them working through the list of problems, the game, although playable in some ways, was still deeply flawed.  Archers still wouldnt retaliate, still had issues placing simple things like stairs up to walls).About a year after launch:  I decide to give the game one last try.  (Loved earlier Stronghold titles and the concept in general).  They made some improvements to the game .. archers could fire back .. structures could be placed .. overall the game became somewhat playable .. BUT .. even after all that work they really barely achieve 'passable' .. archers may retaliate, but there's no mechanic for wall cover, and they get no elevation bonus to range or accuracy .. so basically 20 archers attacking a wall v 20 archers on a wall .. probably the attackers would win because they are clustered into one big kill-group, firing all their arrows together accurately, while the wall guys are scattered about and some would be out of range to attack... but yeah, basically the ones on the wall get no benefit).  Also you'll place units on a wall and they will become un-movable.  Just plain stuck.So basically, despite a good legacy and concept, the game sucks.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
2/10Overall, don't buy the game. Its terrible... It doesn't live up to the Stronghold series. Don't even buy it on a sale even if its $7.49. Go buy a small game with 8 dollars, you can probably find something with more playability. Go ahead and buy those cheap DLCs or cosmetics you've been wanting for your other games. Go ahead... its much better to buy cosmetic DLCs or small packs then it is to buy this game.CategoryRatingGraphics8/10 The games graphics are probably the best in the Stronghold series, but there are problems stated about this belowModes2/10 The lack of modes is terrible, there is no more skirmishes, there is a great lack of siege battles (and those siege battles are pathetic). There is no built in editor either.Campaign1/10 The campaign is terrible! I haven't even got through the first mission it was SO poor!Building placement3/10 This is a true horror. They added a nice new way to rotate buildings, but the downside is, it takes longer to place buildings now! But whats worse is the spaceing! You can't place buildings closer than 6 feet now! Buildings are so spaced, but the maps (which I won't do a category on) are also terrible! You can only place buildings on 1/4 of the map, because of the elevation, and the strict limits! You have to be careful of where you place, and you can only place so few buildings because of the stupid placement system.Bugs and crashes4/10 I myself haven't saw much bugs (but I have heard of a lot) But crashes, theres a lot of that too. Not even 2 hours, and I already had a crash. The first Stronghold is more stable with crashes, even though I have Windows 8 and no compability mode on!How it runs2/10 LAG LAG LAG and low FPS. I really don't know if its my computer or the game, but it has a low FPS. Other people have stated there was lag though. But it is bad... I can run 800 people with a small castle on the map in Stronghold 2 on high graphics, here I can't run 100 people on the map with even medium graphics. Avoid.ExtraOnce, a Youtuber named DiplexHeated said,"The buildings are terrible. It all just feels like a village, unlike a castle you'd see in Stronghold 2."

number of helpful: 212 of 228 people (93%) found this review helpful17 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												Have I not reveiwed this stinker yet? Geeze, it was like... two years ago now I played (and beat) it?Personally, I don't care about the bugs, of which there really arn't THAT many compared to earlier Stronghold titles. The game worked okay for me and I got through the campaign without any real serious issue.No, where I got upset, where I feel the devs truly betrayed everything that Stronghold stood for, was thinking I was no longer smart enough to build my own castles. That's right, its Stronghold, a castle building sim, in which you don't build castles. On every single player map the castle is already built for you. Oh sure, you can build a wall between two incredibly obvious cliffs to seal off a supposed weak point, but I wanted to build frickin' castles. The first game let you build castles. The first game said "Here's some land. There's a quarry. Choose where to place your stockpile ANYWHERE on the map and, oh, by the way, you're getting attacked in about ten minutes." That's what made Stronghold, Stronghold for me. Sure, they still gave you some castles in Stronghold 1, but they usually destroyed them in the first assault and made you rebuild them, often having to scrap some of the infastructure so you could pull your defenses back to a more practical postion. Stronghold 2 backed off of that, but still allowed for it, and on the missions you were given a castle to start, they were often little more than a ring wall and a single scout tower just to get you through the first attack. Stronghold 3... gives you a full castle on most maps, doesn't want to let you decide where to place defenses (and fights you tooth and nail when you try), and on the rare occasion you don't start with a fully loaded bastion, the places they want you to build are painfully obvious. In short, they've made what once was a good castle building sim into a below average Midieval RTS. For shame.Throwing salt on the wound is the way they handled the story. The original Stronghold's story was pretty good, and the characters were humorous, colorful, and fun to listen to. Yah, they had dialouge in the first game. Good dialogue. In the first game you were supposed to be afraid of The Wolf. You would panic when he attacked your early castles, and the final two missions against him featured huge battles that saw nearly complete destruction of the castles involved.  Comparitively, the Wolf of Stronghold 3 is a has been that should have stayed gone. Unfortunately this reflects on the protagonist as well who, while a capable military leader in the first game, might as well be a court jester in the third. Even the last few battles, where you go up against the Wolf himself, are so toned down it might as well be a sprawling bar fight. In the end, I was actually happy the game ended the way it did, they both deserved it.TLDR: If you've never played Stronghold, get the first game. It's infinitely better than this turd, and you actually get to build castles.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												Bad pathfinding and bugs, glitches, and hell knows what else beyond comprehension plague this game. I have gotten hours of enjoyment out of it, but that was only because I am a die-hard stronghold fan. Anything less will find no enjoyment in this game, only the frustration of trying to get not everything, but ANYthing at all to work the way you want it to. There are only 2 solid points to this game - the graphics and the gridless building system, both of which are the best in the series as of the time of this review. The military units don't behave properly and have minimal AI on their own...there IS no AI for enemy opponents whatsoever, meaning more often than not they sit there doing ♥♥♥♥all until you go to them instead, there are massive game-breaking glitches with the physics and pathfinding, and the multiplayer servers are so god awful that they had to slap a 150 troop limit and 125 building limit (INCLUDING TOWERS AND GATEHOUSES) into the multiplayer to make it barebones functional and you can still expect massive lag left and right - not computer lag, but network lag where the whole game will slow to a crawl.Want the bonuses of a 3D stronghold game that doesn't suck and has functional multiplayer? Go get crusader 2.Otherwise just get ANY game in the series besides this one. This is the ONLY game in the entire series that I would not recommend, as it is the only one that provides more frustration than it does fun - the next worst in the series falls to Stronghold Legends, which is not nearly as bad as this and is easily playable and enjoyable.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												-If you are a Stronghold fan, do NOT buy this game. The frustration is painful and not worth it.-I have always been a Stronghold fan and wouldn't hesitate to recommend Stronghold, Stronghold 2, Stronghold Crusader or even Stronghold Legends to any of my friends. So of course I was biding my time until the game finally released and squandered $60 on it. I'd equate the anticipation level of buying it and actual gameplay akin to Duke Nukem Forever.While there certainly are positives: the game is gorgeous when rendered and boasts a lot of new content. The basics that make the game flow and playable are the worst in the series. As much as I would like to rant as to how Firefly could botch a release so badly after having released a prior version, Stronghold Crusader Extreme, wherein the player could field an army of up to 10,000 troops and limitless buildings, I have no idea.The number 1 issue that ruined the game for me was the slow replenishment of the player's campfire (distributable population) mixed with the prioritzation of industry over military. For instance if an opposing army kills the workers of any industry buildings beyond your walls, or even wolves for that matter, you will not be able to build any troops until the workers are replenished in the order that they were killed. Unfortunately that is just one glitch of many that should have been cleaned up during simple game testing. Whoever was in charge of cleaning up this game ought to have used Lemon Pledge.

The game sucks your PCs performance despite there being 1/100 of the amount of stuff to process compared to the Total War games. MULTIPLAYER LOBBYS ARE DEAD.RATING: 4/10EDIT: Fixed 2 typos.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												I'm writing this three years after launch. Don't be fooled by the frequent discounts, there's a reason this game is *always* on sale:STRONGHOLD 3 IS CRAP.  Even if they were giving it away, it would still not be worth the download. It's a messy, buggy resource hog. In my first experience, the game would freeze for 10 seconds every minute or so. I endured that BS for ten minutes and then it crashed. Most of the three hours I got out of this game were spent in the map editor. None of the maps I made could be played. I've made a large map exactly the same way I used to do in SH2. It failed to load. I've reduced the large map to a single castle with a few trees around it. No enemies, no animals, not even a river. It failed to load as well. I was able to load a medium custom map but the game would keep freezing over and over, making it unplayable. I couldn't even play the campaign. As the "game" was only taking space in my HDD, I uninstalled it. Even if you're into games that crash often and slow down to a crawl for no apparent reason when you're running it on a machine that's WAY above the recommended specs, there's a lot of better options out there. Even if you're a die-hard Stronghold fan like I used to be, and if by some miracle you can get it to run, you will find out that Stronghold 3 brings less of the same, as they removed several cool features that were present in SH2. Support is nonexistent as developers did not deem it commercialy viable to keep patching this failure of a game and have decided long ago to focus on their next rip-off instead, so it's pretty much abandoned now. All the patches this game will ever receive have already been released and they weren't nearly enough to solve the major issues that still plague this title. FireFly will have a hard time convincing me to buy anything from them in the future. My advice? Go waste your money somewhere else. This is not the entertainment you're looking for.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												I preordered this game for $50 and to date that is the most I have ever been robbed by a game purchase. I remember watching and interview with the lead developer before the game came out where he expressed they'd learnt from all the fan feedback from stronghold 2... Apparently all they learnt from it was how to make a crappier game then their previous titles.Stonghold 2 is not generally considered the favourite in the series, but comparing 3 to 2... 2 wins. 3 has absolutely no redeeming gameplay features. Visually it looks better (excepting personal taste) but even the lauded features like wall destruction physics which are nice to look at in actual fact make the gameplay much worse. I have never before played a game where the walls are hands down the worst place to position your archers... They will recieve no extended range, no cover, and are more vulnurable as they will fall to their death when the enemies weakest units chips down your stone walls in seconds with their daggers. Pretty much the opposite of a castle "sim".The ecconomic sim is also suffered. Smaller maps and bigger building footprints means you can't construct a small castle town let alone a complex one. Clunkier interface, less building options, dumber AI (how do you even achieve that?) and all around less content makes this a step backwards from the series previous installments in pretty much ever single way except graphics rendering.If I could get my money back I would because I don't think I have ever been more disapointed in a studio... This is the game that was the straw that broke the camels back as far as my personal policy on preordering games goes. As it stands I wont even consider getting stronghold 4 until it's been out for a year, has 8 out of 10 reviews and I've had the opertunity to try a demo.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												One of the biggest letdowns of my life. I was looking forward to this because I am a big fan of the Stronghold franchise, and when I was led to believe that Firefly was finally going back to their roots and cutting the gimmicks, the reviews for this game begin to reel out and that was where my disappointment begun to happen. It's just so horribly put together compared to older Stronghold titles to the point where any longtime Stronghold fan would find it absolutely cringeworthy. There's also this issue where if you redirect a unit's goal location, they pause for a brief moment before continuing to the newly-directed location, no other Stronghold game does this and it's absolutely infuriating. It's a lot better now than it was at release, though. They managed to patch up a lot of problems, but the damage has already been done. It's been said that this game's bad release is due to Firefly Studios being forced to release before it was finished by their publisher. If you're new to the Stronghold franchise you'll probably find more enjoyment in this than I, otherwise just buy Stronghold Crusader HD on Steam, you'll get a much better experience.

												Well I'm certainly glad I tried the game.. Now I can safely say: Don't buy this hunk of junk. Instead, go watch the 'Heroes' or 'Breaking Bad' series, potentially 'The Mentalist' and 'Supernatural' along with 'The Vikings' as well. It's FAR more worth your money and time (to clarify, as they are amazing series).Sadly, the Stronghold series has had a special place in my heart since day 1. I LOVED the first, the second just as much and Stronghold: Legends was one of my all time favourites for RTS (I know a lot didn't like the fantasy mix, but I enjoyed the slightly difference for once, of course the original was there should I get bored).Then they announced SH3: My life was almost complete.They released SH3: My life WAS complete.I played SH3: My life was thrown into a well with a giant slab of steel tied around my ankles...This game takes nothing from the previous ones that made them so good (other than the storyline, which personally was a little cheap as it's basically the same damn missions). The missions maps are horrific and restricting, the combat is god awful and nothing like the orginals when it comes to army management and the list goes on and on. I'm sure you can read other reviews and here the same story.Go look at Anno 2245, out soon and I CANNOT wait. I know it's SciFi and not medieval, but Anno 2070 was one of my favourites and I highly recommend that to any RTS fan. As for a modern 'SH3' but a good one: Sorry I don't know any at all for you. I've been looking for a while and sadly keep coming back to this one :(Happy gaming!

number of helpful: 183 of 289 people (63%) found this review helpful10 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												It took me a long time to finally beat this game, but I am proud to say I have done it. Stronghold 3 is an interesting addition to the series. It adds incredible depth into the story and lore of Stronghold series. If anyone has played Stronghold Kingdoms many of the ideas for how that game is played come from Stronghold 3. I personally think this game is a fun game with an incredible campaign. But in all honesty there are a lot of problems and I won't hesitate to list them all out for you. Military Campaign:Stronghold 3 starts off after Stronghold 1, essentially skipping what is the terrible tales of Stronghold 2. With improved voice acting and better cinematic (realizing that using in game graphics for cinematics was an awful idea - thanks Stronghold 2) Stronghold 3 creates a story which really revives the series. Set ten years in the future you play "The Boy", the main character of the original stronghold series. In this tale enemies attack the kingdom you worked so hard to restore pushing you out of the capital. You must recuperate and slowly retake your kingdom. To do this you fight off the offspring of The Rat, The Pig, and a new foe The Jackal. Throughout the story you figure out a much greater foe exists  The Wolf and he is back for vengeance. Economic Campaign:In the economic campaign you play Lady Catherine who is trying to rebuild the country, particularly the Abbey, after the war has ended. In this you must complete tests by meeting economic growth factors. The Economic Campaign shies away from military and allows you to play a game featured on running the day to day life of a castle. The Problems:What's wrong with this game? Well there is a lot that makes this game terrible in most people’s eyes. 1) There are lots of bugs; in fact I had to save about twenty times per map just because I didn't want to take the chance of my units getting stuck in walls or random places. On a few maps you only get a couple units and if one of them gets stuck it can be the difference between a victory and a defeat. 2) The units attack one unit before spreading to attack others. This means the first time your archers attack an enemy they all fire at the same enemy. The wasted attack results in a couple second delay which allows the enemy AI, who spreads their attacks, to hit all your untis. The end result is the computer has killed a bunch of your archers. 3) There is no Skirmish mode, they took it away again!!! I don't know why they keep doing it seeing as everybody wants it, but they do. 4) My game crashed every time I quit the game resulting in me having to sign out of Windows and sign back in. This can be very annoying and at one point caused my save to go corrupt (hence why I started saving about 20 times per match).5) You can only slow the game down to Normal speed, so no longer can you use the slow speed to establish yourself.6) The graphics are not that great, especially seeing as how this game is a more recent edition to the series.7) I could not play with duel monitors; every time I would try the game would lag beyond playability. Now some would say this is my computer, but seeing as I can play essentially every other game with second monitor up and watching a TV show I don't think it is my computer. 8) There is a building capacity; this really limits how you can play in some missions. Results:If you can get past all the deficits the game offers, and instead just enjoy the game for its story then it is a blast to play. I thought the campaign was amazingly well played out, and the story had me wondering constantly what was going to happen next. The dialogue before each mission was very well done, and if you already listened to the dialogue you could simply skip it. The gameplay is much better than Stronghold 2 and the units are much cleaner. The idea of auto-market functions is incredibly useful (you can make your market sell resources if you go over a certain amount). And incorporating the statues to generate honor is incredibly helpful as you don't need to waste space on banqueting goods.I recommend Stronghold 3, but only if you can get it for a good deal. Its not easy to look past all the problems with this game and still enjoy yourself, especially if you paid full price. Pros:+Amazing story with beautiful campaign+Added statues to generate honor instead of having to use banqueting goods+Market has auto-buy/auto-sell features+Trees do not disappear as quickly as in Stronghold 2.+Added nighttime battles. In a couple levels you must defend a castle at night, which requires you to use fire to light up areas of the map in order to see approaching enemies.Cons: -Lots of glitches, bugs, and errors.-Building cap-Poor unit AI-The enemy on the campaign isn't very bright and doesn't maneuver his units very often. -Lowest speed is normal speed-No skirmish mode-Doesn't function with dual monitors-THERE ARE NO BOATS, THE STEAM PICTURE DECIEVED ME!!!!!

												Hmm... where do I begin? I waited until this unreasonably low sale price to try out Stronghold 3. I have been a dedicated Stronghold fan since I discovered the first game, it was engaging and fun, Stronghold 2 added new features to managing a kingdom that were just downright FUN, it was almost like a good RTS/City management game, and I hoped they'd build off of that for Stronghold 3.Well, that lasted a full minute and a half.Not only did they strip the enjoyable parts of Stronghold 2 out of this game, they basically remade Stronghold 1 with more confusing divisions, no gameplay improvements, and similar if not the same unit dialogue.Even at $2.99 I'm struggling to justify the purchase, and it is heartbreaking to me. I LOVE this genre, I loved the older games, I wanted a game that built and gave me MORE of the in-depth stuff, and here I got a game that just... cops out.Even writing this review hurts.

Posted: September 18, 2016
												Let me start by saying i've played all Stronghold games besides the new Crusader and I enjoyed all of them. I especially enjoyed Stronghold 2 and Stronghold Legends, but i can't say that about this one unfortunately... First, all troops walk which is extremely irritating, especially If my castle is under attack i expect my troops to move with some urgency. Second, they took out skirmish which i think was a mistake and very disappointing. Third, when you go to mount walls the cursor turns to a staircase and i cant tell where i'm clicking and it's kinda stupid, it was a pointless change and it was perfect before. There's no attack move so I have to order my troops to attack one target or they all just march into death if they come under attack. The AI seems a little stupid, my troops are in defensive mode and being shot and enemy troops are nearby but they don't retaliate, even in aggressive they didnt seem to do anything. I don't ever write reviews but I'm very disappointed because I love Stronghold but i dont understand why this turned out the way it did. I see a lot of great potential for the game. New structures, wooden towers, houses vary in size depending how close they are to the keep, certain new features i like but the features they for some reason took away or changed completely ruin it, it's like they crapped on that battle mechanics of the game. I honestly haven't played much but that's because i cant bring myself to enjoy the game because of these changes.  I don't understand why it's like this and i hope they fix it. I unfortunately don't recommend this game until they do something about it. ):

content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
												13 minutes in and I can already say I wouldn't recommend this game. I've played every Stronghold game, so I'm looking at SH3 in comparison to the other entries in the series.I went into the game expecting utter garbage based on the reviews I've seen. Was it? No, I don't think so. For starters, this is definitely the best looking game in the series. Unfortunately, a few things bother me too much to consider playing it over the other SH titles. FIrst of all, NO CUSTOM SKIRMISH. This means, you can only play missions they give you. Custom skirmishes are my favorite part of any SH game, so not including them here really cuts down on replayablity. Another issue is the troop movement speed. Troops don't run. They mosey into combat. This makes gameplay incredibly slow and anticlimactic, which is enough for me to not bother continuing with the game. Which sucks, the game does look nice (for a SH game) and I really enjoy how there is no grid-based building in this game. I could look past other various tiny glitches not worth complaining about, but the troop speed really kills this game for me. If they included custom skirmishes I may have been able to look past this, but not being a huge fan of Stronghold missions to begin with, this game sadly isn't worth it to me. Luckily, Stronghold Crusader 2 fixed those issues, so at least Firefly learned from their mistake!EDIT: 99% of my time in game was idling for card drops, I didn't continue to play it for 4 hours.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												I took a chance with my four dollars plus change and got it.  Glad I did.  In spite of all the hate that has been heaped on this game, it has a certain appeal.  That is, if you like town/castle building, hoarding resources, ordering peasants around, and seeing your enemies crushed and driven before you; while listening to the lamentation of their women.  Soundtrack is fitting for a feudal lord, but John Barley Corn tends to play a tad too often, and the lyrics remind me of brave Sir Robin.  Graphically, the landscapes are rendered like impressionistic oil paintings, which is fitting for this genre, although not for this time period.  Also, if you've got a hankering for medieval architecture, you'll be treated to variety of historically accurate building styles; a few have given me ideas for building defenses in other games like 7 Days to Die.  The one thorn in my crown over this game is multi-player because I can never connect.  However, for the sale price the single player modes are worth it, and real feudal lords didn't have an internet for their multi-player games either.  I give it two forks up!  (Note: One of the forks is somewhat bent from jamming it in my ethernet port while trying to get multi-player to work.)

number of helpful: 17 of 21 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2012
												Stronghold 3 may look like a medieval fortress simulator where feudal armies throw themselves against vast layers of fortifications with thick walls and towers that look as if they reach the skies. This is unfortunately only true if you play one of the scenarios that feature already constructed fortifications. Throughout the rest of the game you will never get to build anything more than a few haphazardly placed walls and the occasional watch tower.The problem with Stronghold 3 is it's speed. Everything moves at a dreadfully slow pace. Gathering resources and building structures seem to take forever and most of the game seems to take place without any interaction from you, simply waiting for something to happen. The extremely tiny maps doesn't help either, making every town feel cramped.You play as a feudal lord starting every map with your, very small, castle and some starting peasants. As you build resource gathering structures or conscript soldiers those peasants get used up and to attract more you need to provide them with adequate housing, food and not as much plague as you would like to inflict upon the lazy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.As your town grows you start to get involved in the more costly resources as well as the more complicated resource chains letting you equip your army better and feed your populace more sufficiently. Along the way and depending on the scenario or campaign mission you're on you might face the additional threat of invading armies or super aggressive wolves that'll kill your poor defenseless peasants and put a stop to production until you can attract some more.The problem with economic and city-building aspects of the game is as mentioned before, the speed. Everything happens at a snail's pace. You place your initial resource gathering buildings, got get a cup of coffee, come back and place the another resource gather. You repeat this process until you get enough of an income to start placing the more advanced resource harvesters as well as building the beginnings of an army and then you go get a cup of coffee and come back when you've got enough resources to place another advanced harvester or recruit another soldier. You spend more time waiting than actually playing the game and that is a serious design flaw.I am normally all for slow paced intelligent games but this is just ridiculous and the slow speed adds nothing to the game's depth.The military aspects of the game is predictably simple. You harvest resources to construct weapons and then use those weapons to conscript your peasants into military service as a variety of different types of soldiers. The actual combat however pretty much boils down to box selecting your army and clicking attack on the enemy army, hoping you got the right numbers and combination of troops.Graphically there is nothing wrong with the game but not much right either. It neither adds nor detracts much from the experience. The sounds are comfortably boring although the soundtrack does feature some neat flute music that fits the genre very nicely.All in all Stronghold suffers from two serious design flaws that takes it from being a great idea to a bad game. The slow speed makes the game boring and any sense of accomplishment you get from finally getting a proper economy working is instantly removed when a new map starts and you are thrown back to square one having to rebuild. The lack of proper fortress building however is what truly kills it for me. You will never come to a point in the game where building those mighty fortifications that is the game's trademark becomes natural. It takes far too long to get there and once you do you could probably have won the map three times over.Stick to the older titles in the series or looks elsewhere, this is not a game that delivers what it promised.

												This is one of those games that didn't exceed the ones before it. Stronghold holds a very special place in gaming as it holds castle building, fighting and economics in equel amounts. Even though it's dated, I'd prefer to play Stronghold Crusader, at least there's a lot of creative control there.+3D Graphics+Soundtrack-Meh Combat-Castle Building-It's 3D, but the game is still very aged feeling.5/10

number of helpful: 13 of 19 people (68%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Grade 4/10Stronghold series has been in deep trouble and continues to do so. That is very sad thing, because I really liked the original stronghold games. Buy either original Stronghold or Stronghold Crusader or wait and hope that the Stronghold Crusader 2 will be better.Full review:The developers of Stronghold 3 said that they attempted to return back to the roots of original Stronghold games after that Stronghold 2 and Stronghold Legends had been disappointments. Personally I don't see that much resemblance between original Stronghold games and Stronghold 3. This might not have been the problem, because this series might require refreshing instead of going back to roots. Whatever the developers tried to do, the game is a failure. This result was heavily affected by the fact that the publisher pushed the game to markets before it was ready. Now the game doesn't have any game braking bugs anymore but some annoying bugs still exist and the gameplay just isn't nearly as good as it should be.I'll start with the gameplay. The gamplay is too slow. The gameplay in the actual Stronghold games has always been slower than in the Crusader versions to place more value on the economy but in this game the gameplay is just too slow. The units are too slow and also the economy is also extremely slow. Even new citizens spawn too slowly. The result of this is that the army sizes are extremely low as well as the size of the castle.Next i'll talk more specifically about the economy. The economy in this game seems to be very difficult to manage. It seems like that no matter the player does, the player is all the time on the edge of collapse of the economy even if the enemies don't attack you castle. Even worse is how popularity is calculated. Before this game the popularity was very stable once the most basic needs of the citisens were secured. In Stronghold Crusader 3 however the popularity changes all the time because a) the economy is all the time on the edge of collapseb) amount of population has drastic effect on popularityc) Popularity is always going up or down unlike in previous game in which it was easy to have stable popularity.The result of both economy and popularity being at the edge of collapse is that the player uses almost all the time micromanaging these things leaving no time to build the defenses or care about the army in a game in which half of the game should be doing these two things.Third main problem in this game is the castle building. The building of walls and towers was changed dramatically for this game, but unfortunately the new system is total disaster. It is difficult to use and some of the difficulty might actually be caused by bugs. In a game, where economy is requiring your constant micromanaging and enemies attack every now and then a difficult to use waal bulding system is huge problem. The new system also prevents the creation of imaginative castles. On top of this the player is unable to create moats around his castle inexcept in the scenario builder. The developers have admitted their mistake and the building of walls and towers will be reverted to how it was before for Stronghold Crusader 2.Fourth main problem is the combat. The combat is very slow and units under melee attack are very unresponsive. This makes makes usage of fast troops pointless. In previous games I preferred to have mixed army (because different units had their own strenghts), but in this game only useful troops are swordmen and crossbowmen. Exception being knights that are needed to destroy siege engines.To summarise the gameplay part: Stronghold crusader is a game combining medieval combat, castle building and economy and it fails in all these aspects.Last thing that I would like to mention are graphics. The graphics of this game are awful. Both the soldiers and buildings are are very difficult to distinguish from each other and I also dislike the chosen artistic style. If the developers of this game can't create clear and beutiful 3D objects they should revert back to 2.5D graphics that was used in original stronhold game because that game had very beautiful and clear graphics.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15
												I was a big fan of Stronghold 2 so I'm disappointed with Stronghold 3. To give an example of a recent frustration: It feels like the range on enemies is far greater than the range of my own units. I put 100 archers within 10m of an enemy tower. Did a single unit fire upwards? Of course not. Capapults have to be within 10m to fire at anything, which is stupid - a catapult has a longer range than 10m! Enemy archers on the ground will fire at my archers on the ground and mine won't fire back because the enemy's range is greater. The game is frustrating, annoying and a chore. Population recovers so slowly, you fail an assault on an enemy and have to wait 20 minutes before you've re-recruited another one. And you bet that one will be wiped out just as easily as the first because enemies outrange you and if they're on towers, you have to throw 10x their numbers at them to get through. The game feels unbalanced and unfair to the player.

												If you have played the original Stronghold you might have liked it to bits, just as I did (and still do). Sound and music have been blindly copied from the previous games. The new fighting by night feature adds nothing but frustration. Overall this game gives the impression that the developers were just lazy.In short: steer clear of this game. It was not even worth the 5€ I paid for it.Be wary of future titles made by this developer.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												I bought the Stronghold pack for 2 and saw 3 on the list. So I decided to install it and play since I never got to when I had the disk version as my old computer was crap and the disk went missing. Was shocked to see there was no skirmish/kingsmaker mode. Said arlight lets jump into the military campaign. Cared nothing for the story, but dear god was the unit mechanics horrible. The enemy archers had 3 times the range of my archers. Furthermore whenever I would order my archers to attack they run up into melee range and start shooting. Melee units seem to have an extremely short agro range even with agressive stance, and they are pretty slow in this game( Even some of the light infantry such as Men-At-Arms are very slow). There are quite a bit of bugs like units standing on invisible walls after the walls are destroyed. The animations are so choppy for melee units. Altought 360 building rotation was nice, the building placement (especially for castle walls, towers, and stairs) are a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ Castle gates don't make sense to me in this game. Sometimes they work and open for your units, other times they close on you and won't open. To make matters worst, your units can get stuck on buildings or the terrain and become immobile. Formations seem to give little benifit now, For example in earlier games column formation would allow your units to move faster, but now it doesn't seem to do anything or is so small its unnoticable. missile units have lost alot of value as you can't even target properly with them without getting them into melee range. This game was a major disappointment and like others have stated, feels as if it was still undevelopement. 4.8/10

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												Not to belabor (good word, write that down) a point, but this is a hunk of sh!t. The graphics look to be from 2005, not 2011. The music is good. The tutorial is 3 min and basically shows you nothing of any systems or menus or hotkeys/orders of the game. Funny after all their patching and complaints of terrible unhelpful and uninformative tutorial, they didn't expand on it. The combat is shotty, as you can't attack an area, just click on one guy. Sometimes you don't auto attack enemies in the area. Clicking on places to go is finnicky and doesn't work half the time. The enemies have no health bars so you can't tell how you are doing in a fight. For some reason your guys walk super slowly anywhere you order them, as apparently people didn't know about running/jogging in the medieval times. There is no seemingly obvious way to speed time or things up to not make you have to sit there forever. Multiplayer is dead. I wasn't a fan of strategy/sim games to begin with, and this didn't help in making them more interesting. Didnt' feel like waiting around for the other terrible features that the long fans of the series have mentioned previously. Waste of time/10, as well as 4/10.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2016
												Given to me as a gift, I tried liking this game a few times. First time it wasn't so friendly to my laptop at the time, so I put it away for a few years. Had a new laptop, was in the mood for an RTS, so I gave it a try.One of the things that drew me to Stronghold was its pacing. I don't play many RTSes because I dislike being rushed by them. I like slow-paced civbuilders. Stronghold isn't quite that, but its economic campaign allowed me to focus on aspects of managing a base beyond "you are going to be murdered in the next ten minutes, make that not happen."However, I've ultimately decided I can't stand the game because it's designed in such a way that your subjects are BREATHTAKINGLY stupid. Soldiers that can't even manage basic self-preservation without explicit orders, peasants who will let their house burn down when there's a well literally in their front yard, and farmers who will bring their wheat two miles uphill to the storehouse rather than the mill right next to their field, where it was going anyway.All of these (except for the soldiers, no excuse there when they're set to aggressive stance), have their roots in the game mechanics. But intentionally designed stupid is still stupid. I'm not going to waste any more time with this and neither should you.

content:
Posted: March 30
												Capturing my imagination, love for games, and constant eyes on my PC screen with the first Stronghold.  However, the 3rd has lost it all.  Some of the features we saw in the first 2 are no longer there, as well as some buildings.  It seems that the creators of stronghold 3 kept saying to themselves, "that will do."  Instead of pushing harder to create a game that blows the minds of players. It feels that they have gone the quick and easy approach of get it done and get it out there.  That said, I still wish to continue playing, but the constant crash between missions.  The bugs I have encountered such as peasants standing in one place or not pursing empty jobs in free build.  The map after loading is a shambles with half a building inside a piece of land or under water.  I was really rooting for this game during my install, but until I can figure out these bugs and the creators come up with patches to enhance the experience of the game, it seems it will be uninstalled.There is one thing I liked, which was the hovel (housing).  It has more variety depending on how close they are place to your lords castle. But that is really much it.So is it worth buying? Yes and no.  No for its faults.  Yes, so you can potentially experience what I am experiencing playing this game and write to Firefly Studios and say, "WTF."

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												While Stronghold 3 is the worst received entry into the franchise to date, don't let the negative reviews stop you from picking it up for under $5 on sale and enjoying the second chapter of a story started over 10 years previous with the original Stronghold.I personally find the game frustrating and enjoyable in equal parts, yes, there are bugs in the game which can make you want to pull your hair out at times, the difficulty of some missions is not for the faint of heart and on some level appeals to the inner masochist. This is a game you must play for yourself to truly appreciate the ambitions never fully realized due to it's broken state at release, cry the beloved castle. The Good:+ The price, on sale I got it for less than $5+ The graphics, I personally love the weathered impressionist atmosphere of the game world+ The single player campaigns by themselves are lengthy enough to keep you occupied for a dozen hours or more + Includes map editor for you to create your own eyecandy scenarios or MP skirmish maps+ The removal of the grid means building placement looks more natural, good for those who love eyecandy+ Great flexibility in designing the medieval castle of your dreamsThe Bad: - The dynamic castle design (post grid) was never fully completed and you'll have units getting stuck in the walls which is annoying as hell- The story is told through the use of hand drawn illustrations, if they had been full color the presentation would have been superb. As is, the black and white charcoal smudges feel somewhat unfinished.- The leaderboard for mission scores is offline with little likelihood of being restored- Peasants can get stuck in buildings- Killing pits are all but invisible, good luck deleting them if you want to put another building in your minefield. - The game is prone to unpredictable crashes, sometimes when you are creating a game save. After experiencing first hand the problems with this game I can understand why players who bought this game full price are still seething. That said, I do recommend picking this game up on sale if you've played and enjoyed Stronghold 2 or even if only to understand why the release was such a disaster.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												Well, at least you dont have to add stairs on wall part by part. :')Anyway, saw many bad reviews on this game, so I decided to give it a shot and here is my review >>So, let's start with cons first:There are slight problems with building placements, you can't place on some part of the terrain. + buildings for wood and meat were small, but now they are wood and pig farms, which means it's bigger, you can't stack millions woodcutters on one place and enjoy in wood rain.Peasant houses are in my opinion really bad, cause you will eventually have really big population (soldiers and workers) and you can only get max (10 people per house) when you build near castle, few units further, number of available peasants will decrease, same as cost and size of house. You don't want to place 50 houses for 50 soldiers.Next one is about gathering stuff, in good known Stronghold Crusader, there was wood by wood, stone by stone, apple by apple. Here i think it's a bit more than that, maybe it's better but i don't like it much.Game is crashing, but not too often.Now there are pros:Stockpile with unlimited storage, yes, thank god!!As i said before, you get a bit more resources from single unit. (can be stored in pros and cons together)You can set any daytime, yes, you can even play at night (still, when you click on peasant you will hear "morning, your lordship"Yes, you still can hear "Morning, your lordship!" "Can't target him sir!"You can play various scenarios (historical sieges), and on community maps (although there is only 3)It's pretty and everyone who love Stronghold will like this.nahnufihemathick/10

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												Stronghold 3 is NOT a terrible game, but neither is it a great game. Comparing it to it's predecessors, Stronghold, SH 2, SH Crusader, it has a feel of being half finished in the most important areas. Walls, buildings, towers, traps, all are hard to place how you want them. The free build maps are only a small handful of pre-made areas, no custom map making. The main story continues from Stronghold 1, and it's decent enough to finish, though the ending is really dissapointing! The graphics are better, and they added a few awesome songs to the soundtrack, but they aren't enough to have you keep playing more than a few hours at most. If you played the first games, I don't reccomend playing this one. If this is your first, give it a try and see if you like the concept of castle simulation; if you do, get the original Stronghold and SH Crusader.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Unfortunately, this game adds nothing to the Stronghold series. It even uses the same old voices and same music from previous versions. The gameplay is a direct copy of the original Stronghold economy, and combat has not seen any significant improvements. The graphics are not impressive for a recently released game such as this, and the GUI leaves a lot to be desired. The story is unimanigative, and the missions are practically copied from the first Stronghold. The cutscenes are atrocious; simple black-white drawings with a voice-over, some sound effects and blood splatter. The weather and day-night cycles had almost no effect on gameplay at all.If you have never played Stronghold before, this will no doubt hold some entertainment value. But if you've played the previous iterations of this game, you're just getting more of the same old thing.

Save your money, buy SHC2 instead. Or hey, SH and SHC HD remakes.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												IMPORTANT: dont get confused by the 0/0hours played, i deleted the game before writing the rewiev. I'd finish it completly.I really waited long for this game and expected a lot of it because i'd love the second part. If you dont have much time oir just dont like to read long rewies skip this because it will get longer. Well i dont know where to start with the negative points so i start with the few good points:The Graphics are really really good and i do like them also the soundtracks are great but thats it!It shocked me with alot of unrealistic facts, beeings and a so stupid programmed unit controlling, that every crusade is a torture for the player.First, there is no ballistic trajectory. Arrows, spears (yes they can be thrown in this game but almost as far as an archer can shoot next negative point) stones from catapults etc. are just flying in a straight direction to the target. Doesent matter if there is a ground wave, bigger rock or something else in their way. They flew just through it.Next point: There are placable traps on your walls now like a stack of logs wich incinerate themselvs and rolling in directon of your enemys. Good idea bad performence. EVERY unit wich just touching it - dies. A person who didnt played this will now think:,, bro that are burning, rolling logs of course they die!'' Thats right but the main problem here is: They die even whenn the logs stopped moving! I saw 120 units of peasents (its a fighting unit in part three) dieing because they ran into burning logs wich stopped moving in a straight line. Lemmings would be proud of em. Next Point: One of the main reasons i bought this game was the Sandbox mode and skirmish against KI- Players. All i got was a big NOPE! in my face. There is none. No Sandbox neither a skirmish mode! only the campaing can be played great who didnt like this? Thats really sad because the sandbox mode was one of the best things in part two and i've been really looking forward to play it in good graphics.If i had knew all these things before, i wouldn't bought it and thats why i dont recommend it. To save all of you who thinks this game includes the best parts of Stronghold 2 trust me: It doesent!

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												The game runs great and captures alot of what the earlier games did well with not much newly added. The graphics in this game are outstanding, and show how dated the older games in the series really are. However the detail and design are just about the only things this entry does right. The sheer lack of things to do makes Stronghold 3 fall far short of its predecessors. With only 2 campaigns, economic, and military and a few historical seiges the game becomes boring so quickly. There is no linked trail or custom matches, so there is little to no replayability. Even if you buy it on sale, as I did for $10, the game is hardly worth it.But a least it looks pretty!

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Unless you are a true die-hard fan of the stronghold series, you're not going to like this game. Even if you are, you're going to severely disappointed. Another game that just fails to live up to its predecessors in every way. Building placement is clunky, unit pathfinding is near broken, Countless bugs litter the game and while it is playable (at least for me, some still seem to struggle) It requires a far beefier pc than should be necessary. Many features are from previous games are just downright missing, others seem half implemented. About the only thing the game has going for it... well it's kinda pretty, and the music isn't half-bad. But who wants to pay $30 for something that is at best an ambient screensaver? The historical sieges can be a little fun but they are the only mode really worth playing. Hate to say it but the reviews are bad for a reason. If you MUST try it make sure you pick it up heavily discounted.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Well...I had to finish the game to make a review, both economic and military campaign, took me just 15 hours. Nothing in the game is what it used to be , some changes that were made dont even make sense.  Here it goes:The campaign itself is continuing after 2001's Stronghold storyline, it consists of around 18 missions, some are fun and most are not. I wont spoil the ending, but my *!*^$^ng jaw dropped after seeing how it ended, i sat there for 5 minutes in disbelief, over how pointless playing the campaign actually was.There is no skirmish, which used to be the CORE of what made this game fun. Some buildings are too large, and the maps are too small and have VISIBLE borders that look like naked flat stone (???). This above is covering around 50% of what is actually wrong, there are many small details missing and so many frustrations, this game couldn't have been  a success anyway. For it to be good it would need its entire engine remade, with modern PC's and oldschool game mechanics in mind. I honestly wouldnt even mind them making a Stronghold 4 in 2D as long as it was FUN , which this game was not. I bought it for 2$ and i guess for that price its worth it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2012
												Do you know what my advisor said to me the other day? “Sire, it looks like Stronghold 2, smells like Stronghold 2, tastes like Stronghold 2… Good thing we didn’t pay retail.” I do love the Stronghold series, but Stronghold 3 is simply an abysmal failure.In terms of game play, aesthetics and overall feel, I get the impression that someone just took Stronghold 2 and Stronghold Legends, put it in a blender and hit puree. That could have been a tasty beverage, but someone got the bright idea to strain out all of the detailed play mechanics and structures from Stronghold 2 and throw them away. Why?!Stronghold 2 was an awesome game, BECAUSE you had so many management options and detailed buildings! There were geese and eels in a pond, which was my personal favorite structure, followed closely by the royal treasury. There were lots of detailed buttons and menus when you clicked on structures…And while we’re on the subject, since everything in Stronghold 3 feels repurposed, what was so hard about carrying over all of the peasant dialog from the other games in the series!?! What fun is it to be lord of the castle if you can’t click on your peasants and listen to their simple babble? How are criminals supposed to steal from my granary if there ARE NO criminals!? Done away with gong pits? Madness I tell you!All of that is gone in Stronghold 3… But at least there’s a day / night slider and some weather options in free build… Oh, and you can free rotate buildings… But the walls don’t connect to my castle anymore either… Win some, lose allot? As we’ve heard so many times before: “People are leaving the castle.”

content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												★☆☆☆☆Game is unfinished.  Not only is there a lack in modes, but it also lacks simple & standard features that you would expect from any RTS.  You can get a nearly identical, if not better experience in Stronghold Legends, and that game is 5 years older, and cheaper, and better looking. + Well presented production/happiness information+- The population system isn't a "currency" anymore, instead, a flat value effected by current events.- Bad graphics- Doodle cutscenes- Manually repair walls- Can't change game speed- Minimap doesn't show viewport- Overlapping UI.  Selecting a unit hides the build tools- Walls are no longer dynamic pillars, but preset lines that snap together- Overlapping Controls.  Rotating buildings shares mouse-wheel with zooming- Random events, like weather, fires, or bear attacks can make your population hate you.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												This game has caused any computer ive ever installed it on to crash (since it first released (maybe 3 or 4 different occurences)...coincidence?) Its also sub-par in comparison to its predecessors, especially the original and crusader which is what I'd suggest you play if you havent. My biggest problem with this game is the heresy they call improvement, on what is one of the best castle editor games of all time, probably the best. Going from individually being able to build a custom bastion tile by tile to lengths of pre-fabricated fortifications... Maybe there are awesome mods for this game or some aspect I didnt notice but I cant recommend it, especially being a sequal to such a fantastic game.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												No matter what you pay, if you've played any other stronghold installment, you are going to hate this one. Half the freedom of strongold 2, half the storytelling of strongold 1. Half the variation of stronghold legends.Missions are a complete bore. No variation or sense of progression. The situations you are put in are so painfully lackluster that it feels like yo're doing the same thing over and over again. My biggest gripe is that you never get the chance or even feel the need to do your best to make an ultimate fortress and garrison that can withstand any siege, or an invincible economy and infrastructure that can weather any disaster. They do all this wrong, and they also manage to make the building mechanics truly atrocious. nigh impossible it is to build any castle wall without getting a headache. building costs are also so high that it feels like you're playing an MMO. Long story short, This game sucks.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												I think something that a lot of people left out in their bad reviews is that their complaints are with the multiplayer service, not everybody is an overcompetitive♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥so I decided to take the risk and buy the game anyways. I have a pretty low quality computer when it comes to video games, it's a 4 year old non gaming laptop. I was worried when reading the reviews that the game would not run it all on my computer since the people posting the reviews most likely had much better computers than I. The negative reviews are pure slander because they can't get their fix of online superiority. Not only can I play the game on full graphics, it doesnt even crash like the steam edition of stronghold legends does. I was happy playing because the game fixed a lot of things that I thought were missing in stronghold 2 and still had a similar feel. I think the graphics and day and night cycle are just wonderful as it is so pleasing to see your keep in the night with the torches on the walls sometimes. I bought stronghold 2 a few days before this one so I never really got a handle on the troop and combat system until recently but it was kick♥♥♥♥♥amasing a army of over 100 men. I could go on for forever about how much I enjoy the game and I am really happy that I took the risk and bought it even after all the negative reviews. I like the castle building side of it and would recommend it to any of my friends who I know also enjoy this style of game.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Hello Community,In short: DONT BUY SH3! (go play SH2 or AoE2 or AoM or SCII (my regards to steam! #yolo) if you want a fun RTS experience instead of a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥, if you want to know why i come to this conclusion you are welcome to read on, ive structured my post in: 1. What i did2. PROS3. CONS___________________________________________________________________________________1. What i did:I played the first 3 missions in the campaign.I Tried to play this game in multiplayer mode with a friend for about 45 mins.I played 1 on 1 with a friend for 1-1.5 hours.I played with the Graphics options___________________________________________________________________________________2. PROS:Graphics:- The game looks good (better than SH2) because the plate armours look dirty and not so shiny like in SH2,this new textures also make the walls and other Buildings look dirty and more realistic (which is good in my opinion) in  SH2 the walls and armours looked kinda "blanc". Also other units with lighter armour like spearmen swordsmen or crossbows look better.- There are a view completely new buildings for the stronghold like very low towers (I dont know what they are called in english) and better looking houses for the villagers.Also "old" and familliar looking buildings like the cheese production and others look better now.- Sounds are good, there is at least one new song playing in the backgrund while playing,the old talking sounds of the units when clicking on them and giving move or attack or formation command have been coppied (makes players who played SH2 feel familliar)- there are new fancy graphic options like depth of focus changing with the distance a building has between it and the camera and special options for light and particle effects.(I dont like the change of sharpness very much because i feel like not being able to see something (for example a blurry high tower with its tip close to the cam) very well. but im sure others will like it AND you can switch it off so this is a PRO.- The menu looks nice and is simple- Graphic changes can be adopted without restarting the gameGameplay:- It is now possible to rotate buildings by rotating the mouse wheel, therefore buildings can be packed closer to each other in the castle (thats a really cool feature in my opinion and prevents the player from being♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥because he wasted some space).___________________________________________________________________________________3. CONS (those are overwhelming the PROS by far in my case because i bought the game for the multiplayer experience and remembered SH2 being a good RTS game):About "setting up" a multiplayer game (i enclose the points in "About "setting up" a multiplayer game" in brackets because i cant rule out the possibility that the game destroying buggs described below where caused by my friend having a ping of arround 800 (please give me feedback if others are observing the same buggs)):- In the Host menue several times almost nothing happened after hitting the "go" button (even thou everyone was ready because he had clicked on the "rdy up" button an od number of times). Just a text at the bottom of the screen appeared saying: "game is being started..." (or simillar).My friend with whome i was connected via Skype said he could see the loading screen but nobody was loading (counter stuck @ 0%).----> we couldnt start the game.- Also changing the position of the players on the map did not work when the maximum number of players on the map was reached. i think the developers did not include such a function in their game. (correct me if im wrong here). SH2 had this function. (it seems to me that this was just lazyness and bad work). If they did not include such a function i ask here: Did the developers see the possibility of the Host wanting to change the position of players after the game is full? Did they even test the multiplayer mode?)- When setting up teams when trying to play for example 2 on 2, does "annoy just a little bit" :D because its just possible to count upwards and then reset the counter at 8 to 1 if you click it again.therefore if you click one time to much you have to click several times to get a correct team setup, this wont be that bad if the "counter" would react fast so you could for example click 5-8 times in 2-3 seconds to correct the mistake. (in Age of Empires 2 they did solve it that way and it was okay)BUT: somehow hitting the "Teamcounter buttons" or the "go button" in host screen while being the host often does not have any effect at all, and you have to click again and wait 1-4 sec. until you see if the changed parameter becomes "online".- Also a programme running in the background while hosting changes the numbers = teams of the players which have not been clicked on, on its own if the host clicks on a players number=team to make him go one team up! (as if the host was too stupid to think on its own!)This "feature" makes the host stay calm because the "mini plan" the host formulates kinda subconcious when setting up the game would sound kinda like this if you put it in language: Me and my friend(s) or other players in team A and the other players in team B. Then he goes on changing the numbers by clicking on them and if he screws up something (for example clicking one time to much which can happen with a high probability because the changes wont be accepted always or when they do with a delay :D)The "AI" of the background programme ♥♥♥♥♥slapps the host in the face by changing♥♥♥♥♥♥on its own! and the host goes like: "what the ♥♥♥♥?!" I(!) am the HOST(!) I(!) change the NUMBERS(!)!!!One could eventually try to shout the following at ones screen 3 times in a row:Get thee hence, evil background programme get thee hence out of the game Satan!!!".I can tell from experience it didnt work in my case...(that was a joke).- The chatt in the host menu (which is used to communicate with other players) (simillar to the buttons) often just did not show a new message i did type in and hit enter even if I waited a view seconds. The "lost" messages did appear when spamming a view more messages after the initial one.As you can easily immagine i was staying cool and relaxed at this point in time because i realised that i did pay 20$ for a good load of fun buggs which wood enrich my experience greatly. (this is meant sarcastic).Ingame experience:- Wall building partially did not work ingame for no obvious reason (probably i was too stupid to connect the gate with the wall correctly but i think that also was a bug). Also there was no invisible unit (like the assassin in SH2) standing there which couldve prevented me from building the wall. i can rule this out because i asked my friend if he had an invisible unit standing where i wanted to connect the wall to the gate i built.- One time my archers just did not attack enemy units which where passing by and where in range (at least it felt like they where in range; of course i did not measure the range ingame, thats the job of the developers). probably they have reduced the range of the archers dramatically but im guessing that this was a bug of the "AI".- It seems like you have to click on the ground to see the "building menu" which (in my opinion) is bad, i want a button (which can be configured as a hotkey) to click on to make the game show the building menu to navigate to the building i want to build. i dont want to click on the ground to summon up this menu.I repeat here: DONT BUY SH3 until they remove the worst buggs! (they probably wont remove em.)Better play other games which are fun! SH3 is a waste of your money, time AND makes you go mad (especially if you "play" multiplayer)Thanks for readingand @ the developers: Thank you for making this great game, removing most buggs and making my day! f*ckerz!!its a worthy follow-up to SHC and SH2!

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												I am writing this review because I think there are too much negative reviews about the game.I wouldn't say this game is bad, although in many aspects, it is not what we are used to have in other Stronghold games. It does have some bugs, and the one that is most common is troops stuck when you place a new buildings near them, and similar stuff... Still, same thing was happening in Crusader 1 and Stronghold 1 as well, with exception that in Crusader 1 this unit would disappear, or remain stuck on wall crenelation until the player does something to set him free.Also, many complain how they cannot play with massive armies in multiplayer... Why do we need to play with so many troops? Can we play with smaller troops? We would make some smaller castles, and attack each other earlier with less troops... In the end - it is the same if me and my opponent have 50, or 500 troops. Still, I must admit that I wasn't playing it in multiplayer much, and those games I started - I did face the lag, but I cannot say I have some powerful computer, so I do assume that is the reason why I had those problems. For this reason I decided to play only multiplayer games 1v1 on smaller maps, but it doesn't have to do much with the game itself - it's because of my PC... Also, I hope that we should be able to play multiplayer games with less troops and less buildings, and still, to have the fun. :) In fact, that is another challenge! Try to make your economy efficient as much as possible with less buildings. :) The other thing about Stronghold 3 is the fact that I was reading some reviews before buying Stronghold 3, and I knew there wouldn't be skirmish, and I knew there are still those bugs - so I got the game with low expectations. :) So, when I got the game, I was only looking at those good things of the game, and still, there are more good parts, and those bad ones.Nevertheless, it is not an excuse, and I am also sad that Firefly gave up this game, and that they didn't work on it a little more to fix those few remaining bugs.I would also like to add that it is Stronghold 3 in which Firefly introduced some new interesting things such as: building walls in all possible directions, and putting any buildings wherever I want and rotate it however I want; special abilities of some troops, such as men at arms: they made spearmen more useful this way, etc... Also, I like it more how a castle looks in Stronghold 3 than how it looks in other Stronghold games - here castles are more natural, but that is only a matter of taste I guess.Among those new stuff I do dislike how they made troops just leave the barracks - peasants do not need to walk to the barracks... This is something that could be exploited even in some campaign missions! I also dislike how they made the siege camps just like in Stronghold 2. One doesn't need to bring the engineers (and to protect them from the enemy) to construct mass of catapults in the middle of nowhere.I only want to say that besides its bad reputation Stronghold 3 is not that bad as they say - it is a good game, and we do have to admit that with this game Firefly gave us something new! I am sure that if the game wasn't published too early, they would have done it way better.1. there would be less things to be fixed in patches, and2. Stronghold fans wouldn't be so much driven away from the game after their first impressions, although it is bad that Stronghold 3 doesn't offer skirmish mode. (I guess that they had though/hoped it would be as good to us as Stronghold 1 was without skirmish mode, but in year 2011 we were expecting nothing less that a game with skirmish mode.)Sadly, that bad reputation Stronghold 3 got was almost certainly the reason why they gave up Stronghold 3, and why they left some more things to be fixed... Even if they made a perfect game afterwards, little people would get it. Little people would be playing it, there wouldn't be much of those who would recommend it to someone, little people would be buying it...Still, even though I am recommending this game, my advice would be: don't get this game with high expectations, and still, you should have fun playing it. :) Also, I don't think it is worth 27,99€ - don't rush when buying it, you should be able to find a retail version for less, or you could wait from some sale at Steam, and to get it for less money.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												If you are looking to buy this game to relive the glory of stronghold 1 or 2 think again.  This game is a step waaay back from the first two.  Although the graphics were much improved everthing else is absolutely crap.  It was full of bugs some of which killed what very little enjoyment i got from playing it.  The pathfinding script is so flawed that your army has trouble negotiating simple terrain.  The AI is a joke.  There is no co op options in the multi player set up.  The building options are clunky  and make no sence.  The maps are all small,  even the so called large ones.  This version make building any kind of keep difficult to the point of frustration because the maps are so small.  The zoom in and out optios are so limited that building become very difficult.  Firefly really shot themselves in the foot on this one.  They made promises about the game mechanics and multiplayer options and never kept them stating they never intended to include them, but the manual clearly states that those options are there.  In fact the Firefly forums for this game are all complaints.  The quit supporting this game and flat out refused to do any more work to fix the game other than making it stable, which it wasn't at release.  considering that the Stronghold series is what put these guys on the map this latest release will likely put them in the poorhouse if not out of business.  I flat out refuse to buy anymore Firefly products because of their attitude toward a broken unfinished game.

												Saw the game for like 4.99 Euro in the local gaming store and was like "Hey I fondly remember Stronghold 1 from back then! Lets see what got out of the series.". I quickly realized why it costs only 4.99. Playing the campaign once was okay-ish, and other than that the game has nothing really to provide.
